resources.string: Field linguists and open source developers have gotten together to create a speech recognizer for low resource language speakers. You can use this application to prepare your Android to guess your speech. You need to read some suggestions and then contact WiFi in order to prepare your voice model. We expect that after reading some training sentences you will have a better result. Because low resource languages are different from other languages ​​so we do not know how useful this application will be. You can try it, it is mostly experimental and used for research, so we can not guarantee that it will be useful. If you use the app to train your recognizer, you agree that we can use the anonymous training recordings to improve the recognizer and for linguistics research. Here's our resulting research: http://batumi.github.io We don't use or share your private data with anyone. Here is our privacy policy: https://www.lingsync.org/privacy.html
Are you sure you want to put this datum in the trash?
I\'m sorry, your device is strange. It cannot recognize speech.
. I\'m pretty funny, ey? There were some other options, but I think I\'ll stop there.
You need to read a few sentences to train the recognizer to your voice and your words
The Georgian language is very complex and very different from other languages which were used to build Speech Recognition systems. This means each person should have their own recognizer.
You can choose any of the available languages for the experiment\'s stimuli.
Click on this link to download Chiodo, Marquis, Achim, Dessureault, Nguyen, Royle 2013 which discusses the OPrime library project data collection in a clinical or research context.
Report a bug or request a feature
OPrime: Open Experimentation was created by the iLanguage Lab ltd, an OpenSource Fieldlinguistics company in Montreal, Canada.
On the OPrime site you can access all our issues and milestones which serve as instructions and documentation of how to use this code base.

Special thanks to the Montreal Computational Linguistics community, Android Montreal, Javascript Montreal and the Android Open Source developers for their work which directly or indirectly contributed to this project.

The Experiment designs and stimuli are copyright their original authors, see the Experiment Home screen for details for each Experiment. OPrime: Open Experimentation for Android is released under the Apache 2.0 License. Free to modify the code to your needs!
